title: Using R in Power BI - Ryan Wade
text: Ryan wade covered the topic of using R in Power BI. The abstract of the talk, Ryan’s profile and link to presented material are below.

title: Using R in Power BI - Ryan Wade
text:
Abstract
R is a very powerful statistical programming language that has been gaining a lot of traction in recent years. In early 2015 Microsoft acquired Revolution Analytics, a major provider of software and services for R. Microsoft have since incorporated R in Azure ML, SQL Server 2016, and Power BI. There are 3 ways you can leverage R in Power BI. You can use it as a data source, you can leverage it in Power Query, or you can use it to create custom visualizations. In this session I present easy to follow examples of those 3 scenarios. I will also provide resources that will enable you to take what you learned to the next level.

title: Using R in Power BI - Ryan Wade
text:
Profile of speaker Ryan Wade:
I am a data analytic professional with over 20 years of experience. My education and work experience enables me to understand things from a technical, analytical, and business viewpoint. I have the ability to present complex data in an intuitive way using sound analytical and visualization methods.
I have an advanced analytical and technical skill-set. My technical background includes the following tools and programming languages: Power BI, T-SQL, Excel, DAX, R, M, Python, VBA, Office 365, SSIS, SSAS Tabular & SSRS. I also have an elementary understanding of Azure ML and Octave.
I am a data analytics enthusiast and I have spoken at R meetups, Python meetups, SQLSaturdays, and PASS Summit about various topics dealing with data analytic
Link to material from talk

title: Turning Your Analysis into an API with Plumber - Derrick Kearney
text: Derrick covered the topic of turning Analysis into an API with Plumber. The abstract of the talk and link to presented material are below.

title: Turning Your Analysis into an API with Plumber - Derrick Kearney
text:
Abstract
You’ve imported the data, cleaned it up, and built the model. Your next step is to communicate your findings with others. Typically this would mean writing a report or building a web application so other people could visualize how the model works, but sometime your Communicate step is someone else’s Import step. In this talk, we’ll explore how to expose your analysis to others in a programmatic way by using HTTP APIs built with the Plumber library. Our conversation will include a high level overview of how HTTP works, code based examples of building an API, and how to use that API from different programming languages.
Link to material from talk

title: Neural Networks in R with nnet package - Harry Rowe
text: The abstract of the talk and link to presented material are below.

title: Neural Networks in R with nnet package - Harry Rowe
text:
Abstract
This talk will cover a simple example of neural network using nnet package. The talk would show example of continuous output and classifier (using iris dataset) and show tuning of classifier with repeated cross validation.
Link to material from talk

title: Story Mapping with igraph - Bill McLellan
text: This talk will illustrate how to script a particular R solution for graph analysis to forecast scrum and kanban project cycle time given story links, points and team velocities. This will be followed by brainstorm with the group on how to start generalizing the solution for a project analysis package

title: Time Series Group Forecasting with R and Interactive Visualization with ggvis - Roy Budhaditya
text: We will be discussing time series group forecasting in R as well as ggvis visualization. Forecasting is always a topic of importance with the availability of several models such as ARIMA, seasonal decomposition, exponential smoothing and so on. Each and every method produces different or close to similar output based on the data we use. We will be going through a hands on forecast modelling in R using Tidyverse and MAPA package. In second part, we will be talking about ggvis visualization which is built for rich interactive graphics and powered by Shiny’s infrastructure to publish interactive visualizations.

title: An introduction to the US Federal Budget with R by Stephen
text:
The budget of the United States Federal Government is often a contentious issue. This presentation will provide a ‘rough’ introduction, covering where to get the data, provide a breakdown of the numbers, and links to other resources.
Link to presentation

title: Learnings from EARL Conference - Derrick Kearney and Roy Budhaditya
text: Derrick and Roy shared their learnings from the recent EARL conference that they attended.

title: Putting the R in Docker: An introduction to single application containers by Derrick Kearney
text: Location of slides.

title: Creating (Web) Maps with R - Stephen Roecker
text:
Most data has a spatial dimension to it. Knowing ‘where’ the data is coming from is often as crucial as knowing the ‘what’, ‘when’ and ‘who’ dimensions of a given dataset. Therefore it should be no surprise that R has a rich suite of packages for constructing maps and analyzing spatial data. R’s capability has grown so much over the years that it’s functionality rivals many dedicated geographic information systems (GIS). During this Meetup the basics for managing and mapping spatial data with be introduced, using the following packages: sf, ggplot2, tmap, mapview and leaflet.
Location of slides.

title: Explore Simmer Package for Discrete Event Simulation in R
text: Discrete event simulation is a powerful approach to model real life processes that consist of a sequence of discrete events. An example of such system is queue in a coffee shop. We will explore the package simmer and work through some examples from the vignettes to learn how simmer can be used for doing discrete event simulation in R.

title: Reproducible workflows at scale with Drake - Will Landau
text:
Ambitious workflows in R, such as machine learning analyses, can be difficult to manage. A single round of computation can take several hours to complete, and routine updates to the code and data tend to invalidate hard-earned results. You can enhance the maintainability, hygiene, speed, scale, and reproducibility of such projects with the drake R package. drake resolves the dependency structure of your analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and organizes the output so you rarely have to think about data files. This talk demonstrates how to create and maintain a realistic machine learning project using drake-powered automation.
Links:

Slides presented at the meetup (link)
Workshop materials to learn Drake (link)

title: RNA Sequencing: Analysis of gene expression data using R - Nadia Atallah Lanman
text:
During the last decade, Next Generation sequencing technologies have revolutionized basic, applied, and clinical research. This IndyUseR tutorial is a brief overview, covering the basics of RNA-seq experimental planning and data analysis. The bulk of the analysis will focus on analyses that occur once a gene expression count matrix is obtained. We will cover quality control, differential gene expression analysis, pathway analysis, enrichment analysis, and data visualization.
Links:
1. Presentation html file (link)
2. Files used to generate html presentation file (link)

text:
Join us for two presentation. 1. Vijay Lulla will be leading us in an exploration of the unexpected parts of the R language in a round of R Trivia! 2. Derrick Kearney will share usage scenarios for renv, an R package that helps create portable and reproducible development environments. The package author, Kevin Ushey, explains the basics in his video. We’ll build on top of it with practical usage examples.

title: Golem: Framework for Building Production Grade Shiny Apps - Lance Upton
text:
Lance introduced us to the R package named golem, which can be used to create production-grade Shiny applications. If you are into R based web application development and Shiny, this framework may be your guide to keeping your code organized with it’s embedded best practices.
Lance graciously agreed to do this meetup session for us at extremely short notice. So there were a few hiccups during the live demo. But he agreed to do another recording after the meetup to showcase Golem again which went more smoothly. We have listed both the videos below.

title: Caching Data with Pins Package - Derrick Kearney
text:
This month we explore the pins package. The pins package allows users to save and retrieve data to and from “boards” that can be reused locally or shared with other when used with external services like Github, Kaggle, AWS S3, Google Cloud, Azure, Digital Ocean, or RStudio Connect.
You can learn more about the pins package at: http://pins.rstudio.com/
We’ll take a look at the core functions of the pins package and use the package to update an example simulation to read data from and write data to a shared cache stored on Github.

title: Caching Data with Pins Package - Derrick Kearney
text:
Links
Meetup Video

title: Turning Data Frames into Publication Ready Tables - Rich Iannone
text: In R we can do a lot with data tables. There are plenty of ways to import tabular data and then transform it for our needs. Lately, there’s been an explosion of new R packages that allow us to take these data tables and make them presentable in publication contexts. A package Rich Iannone has been working on, called gt, is great for taking a data frame and making it look good (and more like a table you’d find on the web or in print). Rich will show us some examples of how the gt package works, where it works well, and where other packages might do better for specific needs. This introduction will help prepare you to try out gt and some of the other table-making packages in the R ecosystem.

title: Turning Data Frames into Publication Ready Tables - Rich Iannone
text:
Links
Meetup Video

title: Apache Arrow: Enabling Data Engineering in R - Ian Cook
text: The job of a data engineer is to build, manage, and optimize systems for transforming data into forms that facilitate analysis. Despite the broad adoption of R as a language for data science, it has taken a back seat to Python and other languages in the area of data engineering. But this is beginning to change. Data engineering tasks that were previously infeasible in R are becoming straightforward thanks to recent developments in the Apache Arrow project and the R package arrow. Arrow provides tools for working with tabular data that emphasize performance, efficiency, standardization, and interoperability with other languages and systems in the broader data ecosystem. Using the R package arrow, it is now possible to implement many data engineering and ETL tasks entirely in R, avoiding the overhead of switching to another language Python or using a framework like Spark.

title: Apache Arrow: Enabling Data Engineering in R - Ian Cook
text:
Links
Meetup Video
